item.title: I was there when ‘Napalm Girl’ was photographed. This is what I saw.
item.description: “The Stringer” does nothing to shake my strong belief that Nick Ut captured the famous image.

item.title: The single most important test to judge robotaxis by
item.description: Humans are grading autonomous vehicles against perfection while grading ourselves on a curve.

item.title: There are two Black Americas. Not everyone is happy about it.
item.description: The divide between natives and newcomers shows disparities in income, education and politics.

item.title: A stark lesson about the president’s war powers
item.description: The Constitution, Congress and norms are cobwebs inadequate for lassoing a presidential locomotive.

item.title: Trump’s Nvidia decision puts spotlight on fight over chip exports
item.description: Allowing China access to advanced semiconductors puts national security and U.S. AI industry at risk.

item.title: The sci-fi writer who predicted the future
item.description: Science fiction writer Neal Stephenson predicted the metaverse, wearable tech and artificial intelligence long before those technologies arrived. What does he think of it all now? Host Megan McArdle talks to Stephenson about the future of AI, education and social media — and how his fiction became a window into the culture of Silicon Valley.

item.title: The outlines of a sustainable Ukraine peace deal inch into view
item.description: Trump’s tilt toward Russia isn’t helping, but there’s still a path to a reasonable endgame.

item.title: Trump tries to intertwine two legally dubious efforts
item.description: The Justice Department points to Caribbean military strikes as it appeals an immigration defeat.

item.title: The U.S. continues to underinvest in defense
item.description: Congress flexes muscles by repealing Iraq AUMF and pushing Hegseth to release a second-strike video.

item.title: Cartoon by Matt Davies
item.description: Matt Davies cartoon on pardons at the White House gift shop.

item.title: Don’t blame unions for VA’s problems
item.description: Readers respond to Post articles and commentary.

item.title: Why denying rights to deportees is not unconstitutional
item.description: Constitutional rights, since their beginnings in America, have always come with a caveat.

item.title: My dad is shrinking to nothing. If China fails to act, he’ll be a martyr.
item.description: Does Beijing want Jimmy Lai to be a martyr for freedom? His health is alarmingly deteriorating in prison.

item.title: A marriage gap is growing — and it could spell disaster
item.description: The “war on boys” could be resulting in some women shunning marriage.

item.title: What Trump lets China do for buying U.S. soybeans
item.description: The president is buddy-buddy with Xi and won’t let cyberattacks or saber-rattling get in the way.

item.title: Land of 10,000 frauds
item.description: Michael Ramirez cartoon on Tim Walz and Minnesota welfare fraud.

item.title: How to ‘solve’ a self-created trade mess with $12 billion
item.description: Tariff policy for rice is formulated by a combination of flattery and rent-seeking.

item.title: What 24 fake applications prove about Obamacare subsidies
item.description: Any serious effort by Congress to extend Affordable Care Act subsidies would need to prevent scams.

item.title: Stop the reflexive contempt for the Trump administration
item.description: Readers respond to Post articles and commentary.
